bibl.title: Letter from John R. Taylor to Philip Showalter Hench, February 15, 1942

div1.p: Taylor asserts that he was an American citizen at the time of the yellow fever experiments, but has been misidentified in records as an Englishman.

div1.head: Letter from John R. Taylor to Philip Showalter Hench, February 15, 1942
div1.opener:
548 Grand Ave
Upper Darby, Pa
Feb 15th 1942
Dr Phillip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester. Minn.
Dear Dr Hench
div1.p:
Having some space time, will write a few lines
on matter's that may be of interest to you.

In the Congressional Records and other places, you will
find my name in connection with the experiments conducted
in Havana in 1901, (Reed Commission work was done in
1900 and 1901) The matter I wish to remind you of is
the great error that was made referring to me. The
mistake is that I am classed as an Englishman, etc.
Now the fact is that I was an American citizen
at the time, and had been made an American
citizen in 1892, nine years previous to that time,
and have my naturilization papers of 1892 to prove it.
The more fact that I was classed as an Englishman
because I was born in England is no discredit
to me (Carroll was born in England) but the
elimination of my being an American citizen at
the time of the experiments, no doubt as worked
against me, although it should not have done so.
The above is written to ask you, not as a personal
2
favor, but as a matter of justice, do not class me as an
Englishman as others have done. I was at the time and
still am a 100 per American citizen.

Am just thinking perhaps I am intruding in
suggesting any subject for your article, consequently
withdraw any suggestion I may have made along that
line, however, this will not prevent me from answering
or try to answer any questions you may put to me.

Perhaps, you are keeping up to date with the
literature on yellow fever, however, pardon me if I
suggest the following, which you may or may not have been.

Death Loses a Pair of Wings. A Novel in Cadence.
The Epic of Gorgas in the Conquest of Yellow
Fever by Rio. Lampson. New York
Charles Scribner's Sons. 1939. 518 pages.

The Epic of Yellow Fever
by Dr T. D. A. Cockerell
54: 43-8. Jan, 1942.

Wanted another Major Reed.
183: 607-615, Nov 1941. by Charles Morrow Wilson.
Will avoid any comment on the above recent articles.
